Award.AwardTitle: Future Internet Architecture Fall 2015 Investigator Workshop

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports a Future Internet Architecture Next-Phase (FIA-NP) investigator meeting in November, 2015. This meeting focused on lessons learned and open issues, including metrics for evaluation and availability, a presentation of network requirements by DARPA, and status reports on environments where the FIA-NP architectures are being deployed, experimented upon, and tested.

Intellectual Merit: The range of topics discussed represent important aspects of the FIA-NP program. The discussions are intended to bring out implications of the design decisions within each of the funded network designs. Cross-fertilization of the projects is an important aspect of the overall program, and these workshops are a critical means to do so.

Broader Impacts: The broader goal of the NSF FIA-NP program is enhancing the relevance and impact of the NSF program of network research, intellectual enrichment of the network research community, and the contribution of new concepts and thought leadership to the future of the Internet. The program, and the workshops in particular, are a means to train a cohort of academic network researchers in the practice of long-range architectural thinking. The program has the potential to contribute to a future Internet that is materially more secure, robust, economically viable, and fit for the needs of society than the Internet of today. The summary of this workshop, which is posted on the FIA website http://www.nets-fia.net/ for public dissemination, will be a contribution to this broader goal.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported one in a series of Future Internet Architecture--Next Phase (FIA-NP) principal investigator meetings, this one in November, 2015. Several topics were discussed at this meeting, as follows:

Availability: Availability is a critical aspect of network utility, but the definition of availability is not well-conceptualized. Discussion at the meeting led to the following conclusions. Availability has to be understood relative to the specification of the system in question. Availability of a Delay Tolerant Network  and a real-time network are very different things. Availability is a layered concept. Higher layers can compensate for problems at a lower layer. What matters is the availability of the application/mission.  Responsibility for achieving high availability can be shifted among the layers, and architecture can (to some extent) define how that is done. Availability must also be understood in terms of scope—how much of the network is affected. Finally, availability has a time dimension: haw long was was there a loss of availability.

Metrics for comparative evaluation of different architectural proposals: To the extent that we can quantify something, we produce better scientific discourse. However, most of the metrics that seem relevant to evaluation of an architecture seem very hard to quantify. Even simple performance metrics, such as time to make a connection, are not well-enough defined to allow comparison among architectures. The challenge of quantified comparison of competing ideas is a major challenge in a discipline such as systems specification, which is in part a design practice as a practice driven by a foundation of scientific and engineering principles.

The broader goal of the NSF FIA program, of which these workshops are a part, is enhancing the relevance and impact of the NSF program of network research, intellectual enrichment of the network research community, and the contribution of new concepts and thought leadership to the future of the Internet. The program, and the workshops in particular, are a means to train a cohort of academic network researchers in the practice of long-range architectural thinking. The program has the potential to contribute to a future Internet that is materially more secure, robust, economically viable, and fit for the needs of society than the Internet of today. The results of this workshop, which will be posted on the FIA website http://www.nets-fia.net/ for public dissemination, will be a contribution to this broader goal.
